title: 111_hr2891
content: The "Access to Frontline Health Care Act of 2009" includes a Frontline Providers Loan Repayment Program under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will establish a Frontline Providers Loan Repayment Program for health professionals to serve in care scarcity areas for at least 2 years. Eligibility requires submitting an application. The Loan Repayment Program requires individuals to submit an application and sign a contract to participate. Approval by the Secretary is needed to become a participant in the program. The Loan Repayment Program requires approval from the Secretary for an individual's application and acceptance of the contract. Preference is given to applicants with interdisciplinary studies background. The Secretary determines the areas for placing contract recipients in frontline care scarcity areas. The Secretary determines frontline care scarcity areas for contract recipients based on interdisciplinary health care programs or plans. Written notice is provided promptly upon approval for participation in the Loan Repayment Program. The Secretary provides written notice promptly upon approving an individual's participation in the Loan Repayment Program. The contract includes an agreement for student loan repayment for a specified period to pay off debts from the study or program. The Secretary approves an individual for the Loan Repayment Program, which includes an agreement for student loan repayment to pay off debts from the study or program. The individual must agree to provide frontline care services for a minimum of 2 years at a health care facility in a frontline care scarcity area. The Loan Repayment Program requires individuals to provide frontline care services for a minimum of 2 years at a health care facility in a scarcity area. The contract includes provisions for financial obligations, breach damages, and other statements deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Loan Repayment Program requires individuals to provide frontline care services for a minimum of 2 years at a health care facility in a scarcity area. The contract includes provisions for financial obligations, breach damages, and other statements deemed necessary by the Secretary. The amount of an annual student loan repayment is determined by the Secretary to recruit health care providers into the program. The Secretary may pay a sufficient amount to recruit health care providers into the loan repayment program. Payments can be made directly to the loan provider on behalf of the individual. If an individual breaches the contract by not fulfilling their service obligation, the United States can recover an amount from the individual. The United States can recover the total amount paid to an individual under a contract, along with interest, if the individual fails to fulfill their service obligation in a frontline care scarcity area. The term 'frontline care services' refers to health care services in various fields such as general surgery, optometry, physical therapy, and pediatrics, among others. These services are designated as shortage areas under specific criteria. The term 'frontline care services' includes various healthcare fields like general surgery, optometry, physical therapy, and pediatrics, among others. Shortage areas are designated based on specific criteria, including services provided by professionals in public health, podiatric medicine, dietetics, occupational therapy, general pediatrics, respiratory therapy, medical technology, otolaryngology, radiologic technology, general surgeon, ophthalmologist, chiropractor, audiologist, speech language pathologist, pharmacist, podiatric physician, registered dietician, pediatrician, or medical technologist. The authorized appropriations for carrying out frontline care services include $78,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $93,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, $108,000,000 for fiscal year 2012, and $123,000,000 for fiscal year 2013. The professionals eligible for this program include registered dieticians, occupational therapists, pediatricians, respiratory therapists, medical technologists, otolaryngologists, and radiologic technologists who have completed an accredited course of study in the United States. For fiscal years 2011 to 2015, the appropriations are $93,000,000, $108,000,000, $123,000,000, $138,000,000, and $153,000,000 respectively. Starting from fiscal year 2016, the amount will be adjusted based on the average percentage increase in health professions education costs. The Secretary must implement the loan repayment program within 180 days of enactment.
